div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly..as under for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Saturday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, calling fortnightly at LARNACA (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardahelles, Gallipoli anf Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sedan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

Mail Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sina), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden. For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Fort Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK and SON (Eygypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIEA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: OCCUPATION OF EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Wilfrid Blunt has been criticised having made public in his recent work, "Secret History of the Occupation of Egypt" the correspondence and conversations of twenty five years ago with public men, still living without their leave. He admits that he did not ask or obtain leave to publish and defends his position in a letter, which appears in the "Athenaeum." In reference to his own special case, Mr. Blunt remarks:

As one intimately acquainted with, and to some extent an actor in, the Egyptian drama of 1882, I had a clear right to speak my word about it as its chronicler. To record in writing what I knew was not only my right, but my duty. About that I did not hesitate; also having decided to write the truth, substantiated by the whole of the evidence in my hands. This last consisted mainly of letters received and diaries kept by me. Without them my narrative would not help history much. They were as necessary to it as the foundations are to a building. It was a question, therefore, between publishing my pieces justificative or not at all. What determined me to publish was that history was already beginning to be written and on lines which I knew were wholly erroneous. Not only did the misleading blue-books, presented in 1882 and 1883, still hold the field, but they were being accepted as sufficient documents 'by men who had weight from their connection with the public affairs of the time. Gladstone's life had been written by Mr. Morley, and recollections of him by Sir Edward Hamilton. Sir Alfred Lyall had written Lord Dufferin's life; Lord Edmond Fitzmanrice, Lord Granville's. Sir Edward Malet had published a light volume of his personal memoirs; Sir Auckland Colvin, a ponderous one professing to be historical In notone of them had anything approaching to the truth about the Egyptian events of 1882 been told. All had either slurred them over or misstated them. History was clearly being misled, or kept purposely in ignorance by those in a position to enlighten her. I found myself almost alone of my contemporaries possessed of knowledge who had not spoken. I decided therefore to publish, as one decides on calling out to a traveller taking a wrong road.
He concludes the letter with this challenge to Sir Auckland Colvin :—

With Sir Auckland Colvin alone of those quoted in my book, have I still any bone to pick ; and I am quite prepared to deal with him as he deserves if he ventures to take up the challenge I have now in my history renewed. At the hands of all others of my old friends and acquaintance whose words I have reproduced, I have good hope to obtain absolution, and to reach the end of my days undisturbed by any serious remonstrance from them connected with my "indiscretions."
The editor of the "Athenaeum" appends the following remarks to Mr. Blunt's letter :—

The point at issue is, At what date does history begin? Mr. Blunt can hardly think that his publication of the secret letters of Sir Edward Hamilton, written from Downing Street during an official career not yet ended, is in accordance with the judgment of the best guardians of English honour.

div.head: MEDITERRANEAN RAVAGES.
div.p: Colonel D. Bruce, C. B., chairman of the Mediterranean Fever Commission of the Royal Society, makes the interesting statement that the Malta scourge known as Mediterranean fever is dying out very fast. This fever appears to be widely distributed in the world, but is most familiar to us in its incidence around the coasts of the Mediterranean Now, however, all this has been changed by a simple application of the discoveries of science, and widespread gratification will be given by the intelligence that since June, 1906, when the new preventive measures were put into practice, Malta fever may be said to have practically disappeared from the garrison of the island fortress. The serious ravages of Malta fever made it desirable that a searching investigation should be taken in hand. In 1904, the Royal Society, at the request of the Admiralty, the War Office, and the Colonial Office, undertook to investigate the causes of this fever, and sent out a small Commission to Malta for that purpose. This Commission, which consisted chiefly of Army and Naval medical officers, has been at work for three years, under the supervision of a committee of the Royal Society, and has only lately completed its labours.

It is probable that Malta fever is primarily a disease of goats, and that man is infected from the goat. The goat is very much in evidence in Malta, there being some 20,000 of them, which supply practically all the milk used in the island. It was discovered by the Commission that half of these animals are affected by Malta fever, and that one tenth are constantly passing the microbe in their milk. Notwitstanding that the goats show no outward signs of the disease, they continue, possibly for years, to secrete milk containing the poison. It seemed evident then, that to banish Malta fever from our sailors and soldiers on the station, all that was required was to eliminate goats' milk from their dietary. This step was taken in June, 1906, with the striking result that the cases of fever fell to one-tenth of what had been their normal amount, while up to the present time the number of cases in 1907 has only been five, instead of 312, the average half-yearly number of admissions. There is, therefore, reasonable hope that this disease will now disappear from the garrison in Malta, and some 80,000 days of illness be blotted out from the yearly records of the Navy and Army.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers.
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: Promotions.
div.p: Sixty-five promotions of officers of different grades have been made as a result of the
military examination held on the 25th nlto.

div.head: Public Works Department.
div.p: Owing to repairs to one of the locks at Ismailia, navigation through that lock will be stopped from the 30th instant, until further notice.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O.,Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at noon on Sunday for parcels.

div.head: A Founding.
div.p: An abandoned child was discovered yesterday in Sharia Abdin. It has been taken into a private hospital, where it will be well cared for.

div.head: Murrays Egypt.
div.p: A new edition of Murray's handbook for travellers to Egypt is shortly to published by Stamford, which will be the eleventh edition. It has been revised and largely rewritten and augmented by H. R. Hall, M.A., F. R. G. S.

div.head: Tramway Accident.
div.p: The coachman, who collided with a tramcar in the Faggallah quarter of Cairo a few days ago, has expired in hospital. He was driving the carriage of Mrs. Afred Eid. The ladies are recovering from the effects of the accident, but Miss Eid is still in pain.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and July 4th 624,414 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 331,848 tons were Welsh, 102,460 Newcastle, 107,853 Yorkshire, 42,352 Scotch, and 40,171 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 617,619.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: The latest plague bulletin reports one admission to hospital at Alexandria, the patient being a Greek grocer of Mit Ghamr, who died on the day of admission, and the death ot two native children outside hospital. One death is reported from Port Said, 1 recovery at Abnoub, and two admissions to hospital at Damauhonr.

div.head: Baths in the Nile.
div.p: We announced a short time ago that authority was given by the Government for the establishment of a bath on the Nile between the "Pont des Anglais" and the Tramways bridge at Guizeb, which will be provided with a cafe and restaurant. A new application has been made to the Government for the establishment of another bath on the Nile, but permission was refused on the ground that one bath will be sufficient for the needs of the capital.

div.head: Alexandria Water Rates.
div.p: A general meeting of the Benevolent Societies of Alexandria was held on Thursday evening at the headquarters of the International Employees Society to consider the rates for water charged to the middle classes by the Alexandria Water Company. It was decided to appoint a special committee of five members in order to open negotiations with the Company with a view to the reduction of the water rate in inverse ratio to the increase in rent.

div.head: Fayoum Fishes.
div.p: Certain species of Bulti (Tilapsia) were recently exhibited by Messrs. Cunnington and Boulanger at the conversazione of the Royal Society. The female carries the eggs and young in her mouth and gill chambers. These interesting fishes are found in Lake Kurun in the Fayouim. As a rule among fishes the eggs and young are left to take care of themselves.There are, however, some remarkable exceptions, in which the male fish acts the part of nurse, making a nest, or even carrying the eggs about in a sort of pouch, and these Fayoum fishes belong to this curibus class.

div.head: A New Canal.
div.p: According to a native contemporary negotiations are going on between the Menzalah Canal Navigation Company, the Suez Canal Company and the Ministry of Public Works for the purpose of digging a canal to connect the Menzalah Canal with the Suez Canal, with a view to facilitating the transport of cotton and other produce from the Dakahlieh province and the other regions bordering the former Canal to Port Said and thence abroad. The projected Canal will be about one kilometre in length and will no doubt be of great utility in reducing the difficulties and cost of transsport in the north Eastern provinces.

div.head: A Prison Marriage.
div.p: The Council of Discipline under the presidency of the sub-governor met again yesterday morning at the Cairo Gonvernorat to hear the case against Mohained Bey Ziadi, ex sub-director of Tourah prisons, for a grave breach of duty in having married his daughter secretly to Mohamed el Menshawi while a prisoner. Mohamed Menshawi is the son of the famous Menshawi Pasha and was sentenced fifteen years ago to twenty years' penal servitude for brigandage In his defence, the accused said that his daughter having already been married and divorced, he had no control over her, and that he knew nothing of the matter until the marriage had been effected. The Court will meet again today to hear the case.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S REWARD.
METHOD OF PROCEDURE.
div.p: The following further details of the grant to be made Lord Cromer will be interesting to our readers :—

At a date which has not yet been fixed, the proposal will be duly laid before both Houses. In the Commons the Prime Minister will appear at the Bar, and announce that he has & message from the King, signed with his Majesty's own hand.
The document will be placed in the hands of the Speaker, and after its contents have been read, members will be invited to take the message into consideration on a subsequent day.

Similar procedure will be observed in the Upper Chamber, where the Marquis of Ripon, Lord Privy Seal, will act as the representative of the Government. On the date named, the House of Commons will consider the amount of the vote in Committee of Supply, while the House of Lords will pass a resolution concurring in the action of the Lower Chamber.
It is certain that the vote will be opposed by a number of Radical members, as well as by the Labour party and the Irish Nationalists.

Opposition came from the same quarters on the occasion of the grant to Eail Roberts for his services in the South African War, in July 1901. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman then supported the proposal of the Unionist Government, and after the application of the closure the vote was agreed to by 257 to 108.

Commenting on the announcement that the Government intend to propose in both houses the vote of a grant of £50,000 to the Earl of Cromer in recognition of his splendid services to Egypt and the Empire, the "Pall Mall Gazette" remarks :

Lord Cromer's services to the Empire are not to be measured by any monetary standard. They have been of that quality which only an exceptional genius for administration and a whole-hearted sacrifice of self to the public service can supply. Egypt has been changed from a state of economic and political chaos to a condition of prosperity and freedom in which the only danger is that the people may forget the slough from which they have been raised. By work which has compelled universal admiration, Lord Cromer has made it impossible for any Power seriously to challenge the predominant rights and influence of Great Britain in that country. We are delighted, therefore, to see that Parliament will be asked to vote £50,000 to the ex-Consui- General in recognition of his splendid work As we have said, it is of a quality beyond price, for millions might have been spent on the preservation of British authority if Lord Cromer had been less efficient. But it is a most proper thing that a man who has done so much, in a position where saving out of income was practically impossible, should be placed beyond the reach of financial anxieties and enabled to maintain with ease the high dignities conferred upon him by a grateful Sovereign. Even the present House of Commons can hardly fail to vote the sum proposed with entire cordiality.

div.head: THE REGENCY.
div.p: Hussein Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works, will leave Constantinople after the departure of the Khedive for Vienna. Fakhry Pasha will spend a few days inspecting his property in Rhodes and will return to Alexandria towards the end of the month when he will take the place of the Regept, Boutros Pasha Ghali, who is going to Europe on leave at the end of this month to be present at the marriage of his son, Neghib Bey Ghali.

div.head: THE CASSA REOPENS.
div.p: This morning the Cassa di Sconto opened at the usual hour. The bank was opened at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon and closed an hour afterwards. The branch of the bank at Cairo has been suppressed for the time being and payments and business connected with the liquidation at Cairo will be transacted at the Alexandria office until further notice.

div.head: DEPARTMENT OF MINES.
div.p: Some changes are about to be made in the Department of Mines of the Finance Ministry. The scheme is now under the consideration of that Ministry.

div.head: IMPERIAL OTTOMAN BANK.
div.p: Lord Hillingdon presided last week at Winchester House at the ordinary general meeting of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, and in moving the adoption of the report said the year 1906 had been satisfactory. The net profits showed an increase of £59,087 over those of 1905. The total receipts for 1906 were £T964,433, an increase of £T 19,325, and the Government guarantees paid were £T691,102, a decrease of £T. 31,162 compared with 1905. The relations of the bank with the Government continued satisfactoty. They had always been anxious to render to the Government any assistance in their power in their financial arrangements and in furthering the interests of the country. The deposits of the public and their note circulation both showed an increase. From £T761,000 in 1897 the note circulation had increased to £T1,300,000 in 1906, and this year had reached £Tl,400,000. The report and accounts were adopted, and a dividend of 18s. per share, payable in Constantinople, London, and Paris, on July 2nd, was agreed to.

div.head: LORD CROMER AND THE PRESS.
AUCKLAND AND DICEY.
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey makes some very interesting comments on the statements of Sir Auckland Colvin in his article headed "Egypt to-day," which appeared in the April number of "The Nineteeth Century and After." In the July number of that review Mr. Dioey replies to Sir Auckland, whose remarks on the liberty of the Press under Lord Cromer deserve to be read alongside of Mr. Wilfrid Blunt's statements, in the "Secret History of the Occupation," reproduced in our issue of yesterday, on Sir Auckland's own methods of controlling the Egyptian Press, when he was in power in this country. Mr. Dicey comments on Sir Auckland's statements "that personal liberty of speech and freedom of the press are as unrestrained in Cairo as in London" in the following terms:––

Surely he (Sir Auckland) must be aware that up to a recent date no political telegrams from abroad, even those communicated by the Press agencies, were allowed to be published in the Cairo and Alexandria papers without being submitted to, and approved by the British Agency. Surely he cannot dispute the facts that the Anglo-Egyptian and Franco-Egyptian newspapers were kept under the strictest surveillance, that any criticism on the policy of the British authorities was knocked on the head by threats of the withdrawal of the State advertisements, of the subsidies on the strength of which they, with a few rare exceptions, rely for the maintenance of a precarious livelihood, that any comment on the conduct of the de jacto administration gave rise as a rule to a peremptory intimation for the dismissal of the Editor or contributor whose writing had given offence to the powers that be. From the commencement of Lord Cromer's illness up to the time of his departure not a single English, French or Italian paper in Egypt was allowed to publish a woid as to the character, the causes or the course of the malady under which his Lordship was suffering. No bulletins were issued, no allusion made to his illness, yet the subject was one in which the European public in Egypt naturally took the deepest and most legitimate interest. Yet at the same time the native Nationalist papers were allowed to publish the most innaccurateandexaggerated reports of his illness and to issue the most fantastic versions of the causes of his resignation, which according to their contention were rather of a political than a medicinal character. I am glad to take this opportunity of expressing my personal convinction that this conspiracy of silence was due far more to the indiscreet zeal of the British Agency than to the initiative of our late Consul-General. The plain truth is that, throughout the whole of his career and more especially during its later years, the officials who formed the inner ring —if I may use the phrase—of his Lordship's entourage,, who were "plus Royalistes que le Roi," felt it their duty to keep from his notice any criticism, from whatever quarter, which might give him umbrage and to conceal any symptom of popular dissatisfaction with his regime. Under these conditions Lord Cromer would have been more than human if he had not laboured under the delusion that his rule was popular with the Egyptian community, and that he enjoyed the confidence and gratitude of the Egyptians, no matter to what race or creed they might belong. Sir Auckland may not be cognisant of the fact to which I allude. If so he displays an utter ignorance of Egypt which is almost incredible in the case of an official who has served under the Egyptian Government. If, on the other hand, he is cognisant of the above facts it is unintelligible to my mind how it is c insistent with common honesty to assert that the European press in Egypt is free and unfettered by censorship."
We obviously cannot comment on Mr. Dicey's remarks.

div.head: SUDAN LANDS.
div.p: Complications and lawsuits connected with the proprietorship of land and ensuing from land transactions are multiplying daily; and the task of settling them is going to be one of the most difficult matters. Many of the native proprietors of land at Gezira, we are told, have been selling their lands to several persons at the same time, receiving a part of the price from each. When the time for settlement comes, of course, there will be a great confection of claims; but these have to be settled by the purchasers in the best way they can, as the one that sold them the land will, in all probability, have spent the money he received or otherwise made it unavailable for indemnifying the losing party.

Cases of contested proprietorship likewise give rise to complications. There is hardly any tract of agricultural or 'building land that has not several claimants. The claimants do not generally take the trouble to find or give reasonable grounds for their claims, or any grounds whatever. They make their claim. If it does not succeed, they run no risk whatever; and if it succeeds, they are the gainers.
("The Sudan Times")

div.head: LATE MUZAFFER PASHA.
FUNERAL SERVICE AT BEYROUT.
div.p: Beyrout, July 1.

Marshal Muzaffer Pasha, Aide-de-Camp of his Imperial Majesty the Sultan, and Governor General of Mount Lebanon, passed away at 11 o'clock on Friday morning, just a day after his 64th onomastic anniversary and about 2 1/2 months before the expiration of his term of office. Somebody had made the curious prediction (that was curiously enough fulfilled), that as the past Governors of the Lebanon have so far alternately met their death while in office, the late Governor was by the same fatal turn to have the same end. Although ailing for some time back, and known to suffer from a chronic heart disease, yet the intelligence came with a suddeness that was somewhat a shock to friends and the public at large, for on the previous day he had been despatching, although in bed, certain business of a pressing nature. The immediate cause of death seems to have been an acute cardiac fit that culminated in asphyxia, which rendered the agony so painful and heartrending.

On the announcement being made to high quarters at Constantinople the Sultan graciously sent a message of condolence to the bereaved widow and son, and an unsolicited permission for the transport of the body to Constantinople. As it was the wish of the family to have the mortal remains of their cherished head deposited in the ancestral vault the embalment was forthwith made under the surveillance of a sanitary officer in accordance with the prescribed rule.

The Vali of Beyrout, Khalil Pasha, and the President of the A dministrative Council of the Lebanon, Emir Kabalan Bellama, received orders from the Grand Vizier Ferid Pasha to see that the funeral is conducted with fall military honours. Before 3 p.m. on Saturday, the Vali and the military Commandant, together with all the high civil and military officials, repaired in uniform to the residence of the late Governor, to tender their condolences to his son Fuad Bey. Then came the different Consuls General with their staffs in uniform also, and the high functionaries of the Lebanon Government and the clerical dignitaries of the various Christian Churches. The first dragoman of the Lebanon Government, Abdullah Bey Khonri, acted as master of ceremonies.

At 3 p.m. the procession formed, then marched from the mortuary residence towards the Latin parochial Church of the Capucins, in the following order: all that could be spared of the Beyrout garrison, about half a battalion, the Dragoons, the Turkish and Lebanese gendarmerie, then the clergy of the different Christian sects, the pupils ot certain schools, under contribution on such occasions, and finally the members of certain charitable societies, some of whom served as pall-bearers. The hearse bearing the bier and heavily overhung with floral tributes from private friends and officials, was preceded by another hearse assigned especially for the carriage of huge funereal wreaths, rich and splendid, offered by the Lebanon Goverment and some of its higher officials. By the the hearse walked prominent Lebanese functionaries bearing the bier ribbons, while immediately behind followed the son of the deceased, a solitary mourner, surrounded by intimate friends. A few steps behind, the carriage of the late Governor, with downturned hood and completely shut in by a thick black veil, was drawn by a fine pair of white arab steeds. Further behind was the innumerable crowd. Behind the soldiers with reversed arms, the Lebanese and Turkish brass band played alternately the funereal marches. The harmony and pathos with which the former performed did credit to the Italian bandmaster, who deserves an artist's reputation justly earned by over thirty years' unwearied and whole-hearted service.

The cortege was displayed in full grandeur on reaching the wide square. Thousands of people filled the vast open space, while thousands also clustered on the balconies, the windows and the terraces, looking on the thoroughfares traversed by the procession. The spectacle was imposing in the extreme and such as Beyrout rarely sees. Great disorder prevailed in the rear of the procession through want of proper organization, yet fortunately no accident occured. Still this laxity and utter lack of systematic control on the part of those on whom devolved this duty, detracted considerably from the otherwise majestic funeral. As the vanguard consisted exclusively of men under discipline, order was well maintained therein, but the numberless crowd, that was allowed to invade even the immediate neighbourhood of the hearse, consisting as it did mostly of the curious rabble, and being practically under no control, was a moving mass of disorder. The crowd was so unmanageable that on arriving at the Church the Consuls had to alight from their carriages at a distance from the door, and their cavasses had to force and with much difficulty, a passage for them.

The French Consul General, Monsieur Albert Fouques Duparc, as the representative of the chief Catholic Power, the Protectress of the Christians of the East, took the first seat while the other Consuls General took theirs in the order of priority of time. Preceding the bier, as it was taken in and out of the church, walked the bearer of the cushion of decorations which were both fairly numerous and varied. From the church the cortege continued its march to the Latin cemetery where the last funeral rites were performed within the chapel at the southern end thereof.

The deceased was the possessor of several high honours, among which were the first class order of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh, the silver and gold medals of Al Imtiaz and Liakat, and the first class Order of St. George of Bavaria. He was, besides, officer and commander of several foreign orders. He distinguished himself, more in his military than in his administrative career, having been a graduate of St. Cyr, and the author of a history in French of the defence of Plevna, of some merit. He was a man of sober habits, and withal a pleasant talker and distinguished hommedesalon, although the nature of his position and multiple duties allowed him but little time to take part in social functions. Those who knew him intimately testify to a genuine goodheartedness and an honesty of intention that were calculated to inspire for him devotion and affection. Many have criticised what they consider his errors of admtnistration. If he has not carried out the grand schemes and ideal reforms which he proclaimed in his inaugural address, who knows the obstacles, and who can gauge the difficulties that may have beset his path.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S CENSUS.
div.p: The scheme of the Alexandria Municipality for taking the census of the city has met with universal approval in Alexandria. There is no reason to believe that the Government will raise any objection, and even if the Government did so, it could not prevent the Municipality from undertaking a work, which it has a perfect right to do in the interests of the inhabitants of Egypt's commercial capital. The action of the Municipality in deciding to undertake the census has been brought about by the fact, that for reasons, which we have dealt with in various preceding issues, there are good grounds for believing that the recent census, so far at least as Alexandria is concerned, was not correct and in fact seriously underestimated the population. It has been calculated that there are 67,300 different habitations in Alexandria. It is also estimated that there are 700 schools, hospitals, mosques, religious establishments, and philanthropic institutions, which shelters considerable number of the population. At a low estimate each habitation contains six persons and each school, hospital, etc. twelve persons. This gives a total of 451,800 inhabitants at the lowest estimate.

Another estimate has been made by the Sanitary Department of the Municipality, which is based on the statistics of births and deaths. According to this calculation the population of Alexandria at the lowest estimate is 425,000. According to the recent census it was only 376,000. The Municipality will undertake the work in the coming autumn. The value of a census is for puposes of comparison, and an erroneous and carelessly compiled census is therefore quite useless, as it affords no standard for accurate comparison. Ever since the statistics of the census came out numerous instances of the indifferent way in which it was taken have been made public.

div.head: JOURNALISM IN EGYPT.
div.p: The following is a translation of an Arabic letter, which we have received from a native lady. We have refrained from giving the name of the vernacular newspaper, but it will not be difficult for our readers to guess the identity of the organ whose editor and proprietor pursues such a go-ahead policy:—
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—The undersigned is an Egyptian Moslem woman of good education, with, however, but slight knowledge of English, though she possesses a great deal more' land than the proprietor of the ......................... Herein I tell you what I myself have seen and heard, as a warning to my fellow countrymen, lest they should be caught in the trap and suffer.

I was visited by an Egyptian on behalf of the proprietor of.......................... who had been chosen to beg for monetary assistance from landed proprietors, on the grounds that he wrote in support of the Moslem religion, and against the Occupation. In reply I told the man that were it necessary the sheikhs of Islam could defend our faith, but nobody was aware that it had been attacked. He then said to me:—"The Book says 'obey God, his prophet, and your chiefs'."

In confessing the truth of this, I replied that the proprietor of.......................... is not one of the chiefs, at which he reddened with anger and said :—"Yes, he is one ot the chiefs and his words are obeyed. It was he who turned Lord Cromer out of the country. He carries out the orders of the Sultan, and controls the conduct of his Highness's officials, and is considered by the Sultan as the real Khedive of Egypt, and is paid by him an annual salary of L.T. 480 as an aid to his journal. When, he is finally appointed Viceroy of Egypt he will be given a firman of fall power, will drive ont of the country whom he likes, get rid of the Occupation, and replace it by independence." Continuing to talk in this vein I laughed at him, and in my mind compared him with the proprietor of 4 Receiving nothing from me he went away sorrowful to others more believing, whom he might gull with these strange tales.
I am, sincerely yours,
Saad Salhich Ali.
Laud Proprietor.

div.head: SAVOY PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: The Administration of the Savoy Palace Hotel at Alexandria requests us to announce that it has decided to close the hotel from June 15 to October 1. [Advt.]

div.head: MINERAL WATERS.
div.p: We remind our readers that Spathis' celebrated minerals are the best in Egypt. [ADVT.]

div.head: THE YEMEN SITUATION.
THE IMAM ACTIVE.
div.p: In my last letter I stated that the Imam has openly assumed the offensive. I am now in position to give you particulars of some fighting. The most important event whieh demands trot mention is the capture of Mellah district A force of the rebels under Mahomed Yussef, one of the Imam's chiefs, was marching upon Rudda, a Turkish district about 6 days journey from Sana and about the same distance from here. Overtaken by night before reaching Rudda the force turned towards Mellah. This district is not garrisoned by Turkish troops, but is ruled by Arab sheikhs on behalf of the Turks, and many its inhabitants are working here. On entering it the rebels asked for provisions and lodging, and this not being forthcoming, they attacked the inhabitants, and an engagement ensued, in which about 40 of the rebels were killed, and about 100 were killed of the inhabitants while 80 were made prisoners, and the place was captured by the rebels. The sheikhs amd other inhabitants fled to Rudda.

Another battle, in which the Turks lost about 400, was fought near Ammar, a Turkish district about one day's journey from Rudda. Some 1,200 Turkish troops were going to Yerim and other Turkish places to collect the revenues. They were met by the rebels, and a pitched battle was fought, with the above result and the retreat of the rest of the troops.

It is reported that the rebels are raiding within six miles from Sana, and are trying to cut off Sana. It is said that a body ot the rebels will attack the Turkish district which is about three hours journey from Daala. Al Mikdad, the Imam's ohieij is reported to have raided Beit Ibn Mehdi in the Turkish District Al Hainia.
1,700 Turkish troops have arrived at Hodeida from Constantinople.

Intelligence from Zabeed reports the death of Syed Abdul Rehman A1 Embaie, the Mufti of Zaheed, than whom a more valuable and useful official it would be very diffienlt for the Turks to find. He was for about 16 years the principal Arab judge there, and was an important factor in the public life of Zabeed, and through his influence the tribes in the hinterland of Zabeed were kept to a great measure in check.

Consequent on the death of the Multi of Zabeed and the departure of the garrison to Sana, the tribes between Kloakha and Zafoed have begun to be restless and the caravan route is unsafe. The Zaraneek tribes in the hinterland of Hodeida, who number about 40,000, are also beginning to give trouble on the trade route between Hodeida and Zabeed, and feuds have arisen among them. Presumably the moral authority exercised by the garrison at Zabeed served to keep in check the small tribes in the hinterland.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Princess Nazli Hanem, who is staying at La Marsa, Tunis, is leaving shortly for France, as her Highness intends to take a cure at Vichy.

Captain the Hon. C James, sub-Director of Contentieux at the Ministry of the Interior ; Mohamed Tewfik Bey, sub-Mudir of Guizeh ; and Mr. P. Weldley, Deputy Director of the Stores Dept of the Ihterior Ministry, have been granted ordinary leave of three months each.
Captain MacMurdo Bey, Director of the Slave Trade Repression Department, arrived yesterday morning in Cairo, returning from the Sudan. He will shortly embark for Europe on leave.
Mr. A. F. Broun, Director of the Forest Department in the Sudan, arrived yesterday morning in Cairo from the Sudan, and will embark for England on leave on Tuesday next.

Dr. Engel Bey, Director of the Statistical Department of the Board of Health, has gone to Europe on three and a half months leave of absence and will attend the Berlin Hygienic Congress in September as the Egyptian delegate.
We regret that the Rev. Peter Rndol still confined to his bed. He has now ill for nine weeks and is very feeble.
The work of the Rudolph Home at Alexandria is being carried on by his wife.
Mrs. J Hicks Pauli has quite recovered from her recent illness and wishes to thank her
numerous friends for their kind enquiries.
Drs. Antonio Bruno Bitter and Esther Kenork Solakian have been antborised by the Ministry of the Interior to practise in Egypt.

During the discussion oil the French proposed regarding a formal declaration of war being made before the opening of hostilities with the Dutch amendment fixing a delay ot 24 hours Germany declared her acceptance pure and simple. The Emperor, interrogated by Marquis Ito, has denied all knowledge of the Korean deputation to the Hague Confer ence.
Marquis Ito, in the course of an interview, said that the Emperor's persistence in such intrigues constitutes hostile action against the Japanese which must be stopped. (Reuter)

The Laborite candidate, Mr. Curran has been elected for Jarrow with 4698 votes. The Conservative, Mr. Rose Innes, had 3,930 votes, the Liberal, Mr. Hughes, 3,474, and the Nationalist, Mr. O'hanlon, $,124. (Reuter)

An agreement of all the Powers confirms the Pranco-Spanish entente as only pacific. (11.)
The Brabant Court of Assizes has acquitted young Waddington, who killed Balmaceda, his sister's lover. (Havas)
The Chamber of Deputies has adopted the bill providing for a maximum 8 hours day for miners. (Reuter)

div.head: HATRED OF THE SYRIAANS.
div.p: "Al Lewa" still continues its policy of stirring up the hatred of its readers against the Syrian colony in Egypt. Mustapha Pasha Kamel's organ remarks:—

The intruders' clique came to Egypt in the last quarter of the last century and were welcomed by the Egyptians who gave them fairplay and were tolerant and profitable to them as to every foreignter in their country, especially those who like them fled from their fatherland to take refuge in Egypt.
Enjoying the charming beauty and enchanting fertility of our country, the intruders gave up their days to work, earning their living and leading, a pleasant life.
By and by they formed a close friendship with the Egyptians and appeared as dear friends to them.
At that time the Occupation was in its sixth year and it was a military occupation only. For this reason the intruders were obliged to continue on the side of the natives.

But when they perceived that the former British Agent had a tendency to interfere with the administrative machine of the Egyptian Government, they transformed their deceitful friendship towards the Egyptians into enmity, and went wholly on the side of Lord Cromer.
They proposed their entire submission to him, so he employed them as spies to get information about the Egyptians and to demonstrate to his Lordship their weakest side.
They then fell into the habit of bringing him every day new reports, some of which were right and some absolutely wrong.

On account of this dividing service, he became grateful to them. But they widened the chasm between the Occupants and the Egyptians by their mixing up the truth with falsehood and by the disastrous methods they followed against the Egyptians. For they used to portray them to Lord Cromer in the darkest colours, and to portray Lord Cromer to them as a great tyrant.

The former British Agent went so far as to communicate his secrets to them and to give them his official reports before showing them to his chiefs in England and many a month before their publication.

The valedictory syeech delivered by him at the banquet held in honour of Sir E. Gorst, the speech delivered on the occasion of inaugurating the Suakin Railway, and that delivered at the Khedivial Opera house were given to them in order to publish them after their deliverance at once.
Moreover they were allowed to buy plots of land which are Government property at very low prices, and without public tender.
A great part of the Government publications were published in their publishing office in spite of the existence of the Government publishing office of Boulac.
But the Denshawai incident disclosed their secrets and threw very much light on their proceedings.
All deceived Egyptians knew after the occurrence of this disastrous incident that they were the true enemies of Egypt and that they should be treated with negligence and scorn.

div.head: CABBIES AND HORSES.
div.p: (From the "Humanitarian").

Sir,—For the last five years, viz., from 1903 to 1907,1 have made more or less extended; visits in Egypt each year—going to Cairo and Alexandria always, and to Port Said. From the very first the extreme and unprofitable cruelty to the horses in the streets of Cairo has been thrust on my attention. It is, I must in truth; say, variable, being far worse in some years than it is in others; in 1905 and 1907 it at its worst. This flogging, or whipping, of horses is wholly different in Egypt from what I have elsewhere seen; even in France, and some parts of Italy, where it is so terrible to have attracted the notice and condemnation of the more civilised of the visitors and residents, it hears no sort of comparison with the cruelty to which I refer in Cairo.

To begin with, although the drivers are many of them so poor as to plead it as an excuse for starving their horses, each of them can nevertheless afford a most excellent and durable whip - a long, powerful tapering article that would cut a strip of flesh from the back of a man. The drivers' there, being largely ignorant of the use of reins, use this whip to drive and to steer their horses. It is not used with fancy touches, and it is never merely cracked, so far as my very careful observation goes, or that of some others with whom I have conversed, although many people take it for granted that it is. Its use in the hands of most drivers is incessant, and it is laid on with all the power of the driver's right arm. Again and again I have seen horses rear and balance themselves on their hind legs in a sort of insanity, so great is the agony which this terrible instrument of torture causes.

This awful use of this whip is continuous I have known visitors in Cairo to be actually sickened by the sight and noise of it. All day and all night, unless one can get a room both high and in the back, the terrible sounds are borne to the ear, each sound, be it remembered, representing a violent blow, and with a whip such as is seldom seen in other places. Such treatment of a single horse in London, Berlin, St Petersburg, Stockholm, Copenhagen, or many another place, as I have scores—I may say hundreds—of times seen attract no apparent attention in Cairo, would I verily believe lead an infuriated crowd of citizens to pull the offending driver off his seat and inflict summaiy and severe punishment oh him.

In any movement which has even a fair chance of success in improving this terrible condition of things in Egypt, I need hardly say I will gladly join, and spend time energy, money, and such influence as I may have. I expect to visit Cairo again March, 1908. Philip G. Peabody.
15, Court Square, Boston, Mass.,
U.S.A., June 18th, 1907.

div.head: SYRIAN PROTESTANT COLLEGE.
div.p: The report of the Syrian Protestant College at Beyrout for 1906-1907 has just been issued and deserves perusal by all who are interested in the progress of education in the Levant During the past year there were 878 pupils enrolled. Forty-one years ago, when this college was founded, there were only 16 pupils. To show the close connection between this institution and Egypt and the Sudan, we take the following names of the graduates in the classes of 1906 :

Graduates, School of Medicine. — Antun Jibra'il Hanna, Kharturn, Sudan, Lieutenant, Medical Corps, Egyptian Army. Mlkha'tl Khalil Ma'luf, Khartum, Sudan, Civil Medical Officer. Iskandar Ibrahim Rihan, B.A., Khartum, Sudan.

Graduates, Collegrate Department. — Halim Yusuf Abu-Fadil, Khartum, Sudan, on Staff of "Sudan Times." Abd-ul-Karim 'Abd-ul-Haflz Tennir, Mongalla, Sudan, Superintendent of Mongalla Customs. aud Shakir Tennir, Port Sudan, Sudan, Accountant in Customs Headquarters.

div.head: AN INDISPENSABLE TOURIST GUIDE.
div.p: Messrs. Bradehawe earned the goodwill of the traveling public by their new and much improved "Handbook through Routes to the Chief Cities of the World" published by Messrs. Blacklock. The information contained m the previous edition has been enlarged and brought and the fifty or more "routes" include the recognized tracks to all quarters of the Globe. The notes upon the various localities touched are well arranged and informing and no pains have been spares to render the book interesting as well as useful. Considerable space is devoted to Egypt, and there is an excellent summary of the history of the country and its many wonderful characteristics. The various places of interest withing the reach of Cairo and Alexandria are described in detail, and numerous hints are given which will enable the traveller to avoid many of the little inconveniances of which the unititiated often become victims.

div.head: COTON.
div.p: Aprks une periode de quinze jours de marches monotones et depourvus de tout intefet, nous avons fini par avoir une semaine relativement anim^e et offrant dans tous lea cas quelqiie attrait pour les int^ress^s k Particle et pohr ceux dont Toccupation consiste a suivre le marche cotonnier. Ce n'est pas au point de vue de I'importance des affaires traities que nous parlons, car les transactions n'ont pas depasse les limites modefees; mais ce a quoi nous ferons allusion, ce sont les continuelles surprises qui nous ont ete servies chaque jour poijr ainsi dire. Et de tait tout a ete inattendu cette semaine, soit comme nouvelles revues de TE- tranger soit comme faits locaux et comme de sont prdcisdment ces circonstances qui oiit constitue le c6te attrayant des choses, k cause des changements a vue d'oeil qa'elles ont par- fois produits, on aurait tort de s'en plaindfe. Pour notre part du moins, nous nous dedarods satisfaits, car elles nous facilitent singulikfe- ment notre tkche de chroniqueur, en nous pormettant de varier un peu la chanson habj- t.nelle de tous ces temps derniers !

Pour commencer, nous avons eu du caime k la suite des avis de baisse de New York e|t des embarquements peu copieux des premiers jours de la semaine ; seulement, en ce qui coq- cerne les prix, h 1 /32 pr^s, les cours sont restds ce qu'ils etaient a la bn de la semaine passla L'effet etait done nul et ne s'est gukre trouve augments, ni le second jour, par l'annonce de la decision d'une partie des filateurs du Lam cashire travaillant l'Amdricain d'arfeter pen) dant une quinzaine dans le but de feduire les Stocks des files, ni le troisifcme jour par l'emis* sion de la grosse filifcre Juillet qui s'est elev^e a 75,500 can tars. Tout au plus, si la recolte actuelle s'en est ressentie jusqu'a concurrence) de 1/8 de tallari.

Une pareille tenue n'indiquait eertes pas de la faiblesse et cette impression s'est confirmed le lendemain quand a la hausse de 50 pointd en Am^rique provoqu^e par le Rapport dul Bureau d'Agriculture, nous avons fepondu par une avance de 7/16 sur le Noyembre et de 3/8| sur le Juillet. En reality on avait courupeut-* £tre un peu trop vite, mais quand m£me lai conviction generate etait que Ton ne pouvaiti pas s'arfeter en si beau chemin Rt que les 72 du Bureau, comme condition de la plante,* devaient nous valoir une continuatioiiAde la hausse.i l

On admettait bien qu'il y avait amelioration sur le mois precedent, mais en somme qornme' il ne s'agissait quede 1 1/2 0/0, il paj&issait impossible que le clan Price ne profitkbpas de1 l'occasion pour pousser davantage les prix.

Malheureusement,* ces espdrances se sont trouv^es deques lejour suivant quand, aprks! quelques fluctuations violentes en ouverture, i New-York a fini par nous venir en baisse, reaction dont le contre-coup s'est traduit sur notre marche par un recul de 5/32 sur la nou- velle et de 1/4 sur l'ancienne recolte. La fete de l'lndependance celebree hier en Amerique nous ayant priv^s de toute nouvelle pour nous guider ce matin, l'ouverture de notre marche a eu lieu presque au milieu de Tindifference g6i\6- rale et naturellement e'est le calme et la faiblesse qui l'ont caractcrisee. Cette tenue a dure assez longtemps; mais l'Ange Gardien des haussiers n'ayant pas voulu abandonner ses proteges, il leur a fait surgir inopinement une demande qui a ete attribute au d&xmvert, non a tort, croyons-nous. En tous cas, l'occasion etait on ne peut plus propice, d'autant plus que les vendeurs n'etaient pas legion, et le parti baussier, qui etait a l'affftt, en a profits pour faire monter les prix de 5/16 pour le Novembre et de 7/32 pour le Juillet. De plus, la feussite de la manoeuvre a ete complete, car les cours se sont maintenus jusqu'a la clfiture sans le moindre signe de faiblesse.

Nous nous trouvons done aujourd'hui avec le novembre au niveau de 20 5/8 et le Juillet k 19 27/32, ce qui fait que le resume du jeu de la semaine consiste en une hausse de 19/32 pour le Novembre, et de 7/32 pour le Juillet. Nous ajouterons toutefois que malgre l'apparence de fermete qui regne, la vraie tendance semble h&itante et qu'k moins que l'Etranger ne nous appuie, il y aurait quelques craintes d'une nouvelle reaction, pour la raison que le Juillet au fond p£se beau coup sur la situation.

On nous a contests dans le temps que1 la speculation avait bien plus de Juillet qu'on ne l'avouait on qu'on ne voulait l'ad- mettre, et la r^alite vient de se prononcer en faveur de l'opinion exprimee par nous. Le report de Juillet k Novembre etait encore la semaine dernikre de 13/32 et aujourd'hui il est de 25/32 et ce n'est sftre- ment pas Ik l'indice d'une position assainie, d'autant plus qu'il y a encore une quantity assez consequents d'ordres Juillet k mettre en circulation.

La reserve du commerce semble incomprehensible avec l'ecart attaint entre les deux recoltes, mais comme nous le disions samedi dernier la situation financikre l'oblige 5 se limiter dans ses operations et, par consequent, sans le reveil de la demande de la part de la filature et quoique le restant de notre recplte n'ait rien d'effrayant en lui-mgme, nous pour* rions bien voir le report de Juillet ^oyembre s'eiargir encore davantage.

Nous ne voulons pas dire par 14 que tout est perdu pour la vieille recolte, mais iLy a apfes tout au milieu de tout cela une malheu< T^use position qni doit forc^mentjtj^iqirid^e La possibility qui existe maintenant de se reporter sur Aoflt n'est pas un remade ; £*£Str tout au plus un palliatif qui cofttera pour le moins 1/2 d'aggravation de perte: En qutre, n'oubfions pas que ceux qui soqi/gp ipesure d'encais8er un report sur le mois pjroobain ne sont pas nombreux et qu'^ventuellement ce ne serait qu'une faible partie du Juillet qui pour- rait Atre transferee sur Aoftt.
seraient gukre encouyageantes. mais n'oublions pas non plus qu'^ la bjourse fiojit peut changer d'un moment k l'autre.
Quant au Novembre, il se maintient de par les efforts de la speculation, mais le commer e ne s'y interesse que pour vendre.

Nous avons mentionne plus haut la nouvelle de la suspension de travail pour deux semaines par divers districts cotonniers filant l'Ameri- cain. Cette decision, comme premiere impression, peut paraltre grave, mais au fond elle n'a qu'une importance relative : elle peutproduire un soulagement quelconque, mais si l'on voulait parler chiffres, on verrait qu'elle ne saurait modifier ryellement la situation avec la reduction de consommation de 70.000 balles environ qui en serait la consequence materielle.
Les avis au sujet de la recolte americaine sont favorables, mais pour le moment la speculation ne semble pas y attacher grande importance.

Chez nous aussi les choses vont au mieux et le Resume de Juin de 1'Alexandria General Produce Association que nous reproduisons ci-aprfcs, tant mitige qu'il soit dans sa redaction, nous decrit un etat pour ainsi dire parfait de la recolte sur pied. EspCrons seulement que par la suite rien ne viendra modifier les belles perspectives du moment, le pays ne ponvant que profiter de la r^ussite de sa recolte et il en a besoin apr^s toutes ses pertes sur les valeurs.

Notre marche du disponible a Cte ferme, mais peu actif, en reality, non par faute de demande, mais par manque de choix dans ce qui est offert a la vente. En somme e'est le cas de chaque annee vers la fin de la cam- pagne.

Quaut aux prix, il y a de la hausse sur toute la ligne #t la cote officielle de ce matin nous montre qu'elle est de 1 /4 de tallari sur les Mit affifi et les provenances Haute-Egypte, tandis que pour les Ioannovich, elle va de 1/2 a 1 tallari suivant classement.

Les exportations de la semaine n'ont pas atteint les previsions et se sont arretees a 8,600 Balles, contre 9,800 l'annCe demure; seulement il y a des snspens relativement im- portants a regler et qui iront s'ajouter aux embarquements de la semaine prochaine, dont on ignore encore l'importance probable, mais qui auront contre eux 7.400 Balles pour la m£me periode en 1906.

Liverpool a ete plus actif que par le passe pour les Egyptiens disponibles et suffisamment en leur faveur pour ce qui concerne les prix. En effet, le disponible finit aujourd'hui eu hausse de 3/16 5 la cote de 10 10/16, tandis que les futurs Aoftt s'inscrivent & 10 38/64, soit 19/64 d'avance sur Veudredi passe.

Les americains, par contre, ont manque d'entrain comme affaires, mais sous le rapport des prix, ils ont encore Cte assez bien partages: — Le spot est monte k 7.31 et les futurs clbturent a 6.94 pour le Juillet-Aoht et a 6.66 pour l'Octobre-Novembre, ce qui fait respectivement 16, 28 et 27 points de hausse.

div.head: Graines de Coton.
div.p: Les recettesdela semaine ont ete bonnes pour la saison, mais a peine de moitie de ce qui a ete embarquC ; aussi, et tout comme cela a ete le cas la semaine passCe, s'il y a eu faiblesse sur le disponible, ce n'estqu'i cause de la situation des contrats. En tons cas, tout le mal consiste simplement dans la perte de I'avance du commencement de la semaine et au retour au prix de P.T. 80.

En contrats, il y a eu des realisations k cause de la filiere de Juillet qui a ete de 17,500 Ardebs. Ce chiffre explique quel est l'intefet que peut avoir la speculation dans l'article, et, ceoi etant> il n'y a pas lieu d'etre surpris si la moindre affaire a son influence sur le marche. Le dernier cours du Juillet a ete de P.T. 81 35/40.
La vieille recolte se soutient toujours, mais .manque tout-a-fait d'animation. Les 3 mois ont fini ce matin k P.T. 71 30/40.
Hull est un peu plus soutenue pour le Juillet qui vaut de £ 7 18/9 &£ 8—tandis que les 3 mois Novembre-Janvier y trouvent ache- teurs aux environs de £ 7 2 6.
La situation des huiles est ferme.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Le grand evfeneiffent de la semaine a ete sans contredit \'assemble extraordinaire de la Cassa di Sconto e ai Risparmip, convoquee 5 l'occasion de la fermeture de oet etablissement de credit, Les actionnairee y ont donne kleur conseil d'administration une marque de con- fiance exceptionnelle, on ponrrait memo dire de cordiale sympathie : apfes avoir approuve le rapport du conseil sur la situation, ainsi que le bilan officieux dressy par les banques interessees, ils ont acclame l'ordre du joursans faire aucune reserve et emis un vote de con- fiance en faveur de leursadministr^teur^. Voici le texte de l'ordre du jour en questionz.

lesyndiqjttdga^Banques,' & jAt&iuque trouve la National Bank of Egypt, et i meilleures conditions qo'il lui sew^poesible, afin de.J^prendre ses paiements le 5 juillet courqn^ fit afin de rouvnr ses gnichetB ; et au cas oh cet emprunt viendraitic se realiser, decider, d^sA present^ Jamise en liquidation amiable de la society ou toute autre eombinaison utile."

"2. Dans le cas oh l'emprunt ne seriu^pad conclu avant le 5 juillet courant, ce qui, de par la loi, obligemit le Conseil k deposer le bilan de la Society au Tribunal, 1'assemble ^enerale delibere d'autoriser le Conseil m5me A ormUler une demande pour l'obtention du benefice du concordat preventif, et a faire les propositions de concordat qu'il croira utiles, y compris celle, s'il en etait besoin, d'abandon de l'actif, bien entendu jusqu'A concurrence de 100^ en capital et intefets, du montant du passif, tout excedent eventuel revenant aux actionnaires."

Hier soir, le syndicat anglais k la fete du- quel se trouve la National Bank, s'est enfin constitue. Il avance 300.000 £. La liquidation devant etre dirig^e par la National Bank, celle- ci a nomme deux liquidateurs executife.qui feront partie d'un comite de 4 membres, dont les deux autres seront nommes par la Cassa di Sconto. En cas de ballottage, un deDgue du
mverneur ou sous-gouveineur de la National
ink decidera. La Cassa di Sconto a, cet apfes-midi, ouvert ses portes pour continuer ses remboursements.

Cette malheureuse affaire de la Cassa entre k peine dans sa phase resolutive que le marche tombe en proie k de nouvelles transes. Tout un groupe de firmes du Caire, pour la plupart etablies au Mousky, se trouvent aux prise-t avec de nombreuses diffioultes. Il faudra beau- coup de patience et de sang-froid pour sur- monter ce nouvel orage.

Avant d'en arriver aux fluctuations de la cote, nous croyons devoir dire un mot concer- nant la responsabilite des administrateurs de differentes societes constituees ici sous le regime anglaia C'est, en effet, le sujet de toutes les conversations que le point de savoir si un administrateur etranger d'une society de ce genre peut etre poursuivi pour irregularity dans sa gestiou soit devant le Consulat deS.M. Britannique soit par devant les Tribunaux Mixtes. Les juristes qui ont ete consults esti- ment que, une societe constituee sous le regime anglais devant £tre consideree comme sujet de cette nationality, s'il s'efeve un oonflit entre elle et l'un de ses administrateurs, les autorites suivantes seront competentes pour juger : si l'administrateur poursuivi est anglais le cas relfcve evidemment du Consulat de S. M. Britannique; si l'administrateur est d'une nationality differente, le cas relive des Tribunaux Mixtes qui ont la competence sur les sujets de di verses nationaiites. Quant k la loi a appliquer dans las deux cas, e'est evidemment celle qui regit la society, e'est-a-dire la loi anglaise, car les administrateurs fautifs seraient mal venus k se prevaloir d'une loi ou a la dediner suivant qu'iis y voient leur avantage. Ils ont d'ail- leurs pris connaissance des statuts de la society en apposant leur signature et il leur est impossible, m6me en droit naturel, de violer les statuts sans encourir des respon- sabilites vis-a-vis de leurs mandants qui ne sont autres que les actionnaires. Il serait temps que les porteurs feses prissent enfin conscience de leurs droits et les Assent valoir, ne fflt-ce que pour prevenir de nou- veaux abus.

L'allure du marche a ete deplorable durant toute la semaine et cela se con^oit au milieu des difficultes que nous traversons. L'offire depassant de beaucoup la demande ou plufet l'offre ne trouvant pas de contrep&rtie, e'est un flechissement general des cours qui s'est produit. Et encore si la baisse n'a pas ete plus important^ sur certains titres, faut-il l'attrihuer aux vendenrs qui ont eu le bon sens de ne pas trop deprecier par leur insistence, d'ailleurs inutile, du papier qui pour le moment ne tipuve pas d'acqulreur. Les valeurs les plus syrieusea n'ont pas ete epargnees et e'est tout naturel puisqu'elles sont seules negooiables en ces temps de crise.

Ainsi l'Agricole a perdu 1/4 k 7 13/16, la National Bank 1/2 k 19 5/8, la Delta Light 1/8 k 9, les Dividendes Tramways 10 francs k 300, la Ramleh 5/8 k. 4 7/8, l'Alexandria Water 1 livre 1/4 k 10 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire 16 fir. k 184, laDaira 1 /2 livTe h 13 1/2, la Behera 1 livre 1/2 k 26, la Land Bank 3/16 k 7 1/8, le$ Splendid Hotels 1/8^4 1/8,1'Union Fonciere 1/8 44 3/4.

En baisse egalement les Eaux du Caire de 112 k 110, les Dividendes Bikre d'Alexandrie de 110 k 105, les Markets de 18 k 17/9, l'Obli gation Credit Foncier de 3161'ancienne et 265 la nouvelle k 312 et 264 1/2 respectivement, 1'Anglo American Nile de 4 k 3 7/8, la Banque d'Atnknes dell5 1/2 k 115, les Nungovich Hotels de 17 1/2 k 16, la Delta Land de 2 a 1 11/16, la Khedivial Mail de 4 1/8 k 4, l'lnvestment de 5/8 k 1/2, les Estates de 7/8 a 21/32, TUrbaine de 4 k 3 3/4, le Comptoir de 3 1/8 et 3 k 3 et 2 7/8 l'action et de 3 3/4 k 3 la fondateur, la Building Lands de 2 3/4 k 2 7/16, le Credit Franco-Egyptien
l'Abh
Cotton Qinners de l/16 k. i 3/8, les Markets de 1 shelling 6 pence k 25. t

Quant k la Cassa di Sconto, elle a e^^en traitee. Aprks auelques fluctuations sans importance, elle a bnj. inscrite jk ^8, eu hausse <Je 3 francs sur le cours de vendredi aernier. i Ilfaut dire que les marches.europeens n'ont
gufere encourage le n6tre : le Consolide anglais a recuie de 84 5/8 k 84 3/8, la Dalra de 14 1/4

a 13 1/2, la National Bank de 20 3/8 k 19 7/8 et TAgrioole de 8 1/4 k 8. Il est vrai que le taux privd d'escompte a baisse de 3/8, ce qui est une. heureuse constatation ; mais, d'autre part, la reserve de la banque d'Angleterre a considerablement diminue. Elle est de 38 3/8 %, ce qui, represents 4 3 8 % de perte en comparison de la semaine demiere. A Paris, les fluctuations sont insignifiantes pour les valeurs egyptiennes. La rente gagne 47 points k 94.77.

Il resulte du rapport du Conseil d'Administration que le Credit Franco-Egyptien a prineipalement avance de l'argent a TAgriculture sur marchandises. Les jjfets hypothecaires deviennent, en effet, de moins en moins remu- nerateurs k oaose de Televation du loyer de Targent et de (l'attrait qu'exercent deja ces pfets sur les Eckblissements de Credit Foncier et les grandes Compagnies d'Assurances. En un payspil TAgriculture est exceptionnelle- ment florissante et oh les fellahs sont travail- leure et eoonomes, les avances sur marchandises contiquent, au contraire, a etre d'un beau rendement, comme Tattestent les bril-v lants resultats obtenus durant ce premier^ exercice en depit des difficultes de Installation et la non-disponibilite de tout le capital. De oe que le Credit Franco-Egyptien travaille sur- tout en avances sur marchandises, celan'exclut pas les_autres operations de banque, telles que pfets sur titres, esoomptes d'effets, etc., mais Tadministration s'attache k ne pas consentir

exception dans ce sens est la participation en terrains, qui a donne un benefice de 484.629 fr. Le solde, qui figure au bilan pour une somme de 888.000 frTreste eucore a liqui- der, ce qui sera fait a la premiere occasion favorable. Dks cette premiere periode, les frais d'instal|ation et de mobilier ont ete amortis par le debit du compte de Profits et Pertes,
suit: les affaires en banque et les operations sur marchandises ont rapporte brut 1 560.348 fr. et les operations sur terrains 484.629 fr., en tout 2 044.977 fr. Deduction faitedes frais

die 1.521.803 fr. qui a ete ainsi reparti -.*76.090 pour-le 5 % k la reserve legale, 625.000 pour Tintefet k y°/9 du capital ;sut le solde 10 % au cpnxeil d'administration, soit 82.071, 470.784 k:la feservq.^xtraordinaire et 267.857 k fepar t|r krai^hn de 187.500 aux actionnaires, com me supplement de dividende et 80.357 aux porteurs dn. parts. 8ur cette base il revient 8 fj. 125 h^pbaque action et 4 fr 01 k chaque pari; de foiidateur. Ces dividendes sont payables depuis le ler juillet.

"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

div.p: Le Caire, Vendredi 5 juillet.

Ie taux de l'escompte libre k Londres se maintient au taux promettant de 3 | pour cent Au Stock Exchange, le Consolid<* anglais est demeurl bier inchang^ k 84 §, de meme que l'Unifi^e k100 La National Bank a gagnl J k 19 7/8. Par contre, la Daira a reaction u4 d'une demi-fivre k 13 J. L'Agricole s'est main ten ue k 8. La Delta Light a availed de £ d 9 1/8.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a reculd de 4 francs a 680. La Banque d'Athdnes a avaned de 2 francs A 115.

lei, la stance de ce matin n'a pr^sentd rien detr&sparticulier. L'activitena pasdtd grande, mais il y a eu un meilleur courant d'affaires que la veille, et, aprds un debut assez lourd, la clCture a etd relativement satisfaisante. II y a m£me des plus-values notables k enregis- trer sur les valeurs qui ont dtd specialement atteintes hier. X'opinion commence kprdvaloir que, sauf cas imprevu, il faut s'attendre a une amelioration sensible dfcs la semaine pro- chaine.
Ainsi, la National Bank, qui se traitait a louverture k 19 3/8, a clOturd k 19 9/16. L'A- gricole a dgalement avaned a 7 3/4-13/16.

La Cassa di Sconto a progressd a 55 Taction ancienne et 60 la nonvelle. Il est actuellement, avdrd que le contrat relatif a Temprunt a 4tdsignd hier soir et que la Cassa rouvre ses guichets demain matin.
Le Crddit Foncier est revenu k 680. L'lm- mobili^re a flechi k 330. La part de fondateur Enterprise and Development a dtd ramende k 12.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont progressd k 184. Les parts de fondateur Heliopolis ont dtd ndgocides^ 9 1/2. Les Ciments sont tombds k 30.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelidres, les Nungovich sont revenus k 15 3/4. Les Egyptian ont clOturd k 4 1/4 ex-coupon.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont faibli k 1 11/16. Les Estates sont restds a 0 11/16. Les Cotton Mills se sont tassds a 2 sh. 9-3.
Lemarchd des valeurs dtant ferine les samedis pendant Ja saison d'dtd, le prochain numdro de cette Circulaire paraltra le lundi 8 Juillet courant.

Le " Financial News " publie une lettre fort intAresaante concemant la situation du marchd dgyptien. Le correspondant du journal londo- nienestime que Tapogde de lapdriode critique a dtd atteint avec Taffaire de la Cassa di Sconto.

" Il s'agit en fait d'une crise de Bourse et il ne feat en tirer aucune conclusion au sujet de l'dtat du pays qui reste prospdre. Le commerce extdrieur est satisfaisant et Ton s'attend a une rdcolte de coton meilleure que Tan dernier.

" Il y a lieu d'observer que les principals Banques dgyptiennes, la National, TAgricole, le Crddit Foncier et la Land Bank ont obtenu de trds bons rdsultats pendant le dernier exercice etpaientpour laplupart desdividendes supdrieurs.
" Les pires moments sont passes et, avec les tentatives faites kLondres, Paris et Vienne pour amdliorer la situation, Tavenir apparalt beaucoup plus rassurant. "

On annonce de Londres que le conseil dad- ministration de la Bank of Egypt a ddcidd de payer, Apartir du 12 Juillet courant, un dividende intdrimaire au taux de 8 0/0 Tan pour le semestre finissant le 30 Juin 1907.

L'assemblde gdudrale annuelle des action- naires de la Banque Impdriale Ottomane a dtd tenue kLondres le 26 Juin dernier. Il ressort des comptes prdsentds que les bdndfices de Te- xercice 1906 ont dtd de £ 523,287 contre £ 485,176 pour l'exeroice 1905.

Ddduction faite de £ 74,424 pour le fonds de rdserve et le pourcentage ddtermind par les statute, il reste une somme de £ 470,841, sur t laquelle le conseil d'administration a proposd de diatribuer un dividende.de 18 shellings par action, soit 9% du capital vered, et de reporter knouveau le soldede £ 20,841.
Apr&s avoir entendu la lecture du rapport, Taesemblde a approuvd les comptes et fixd en consdquenoe le dividende k 18 sh. contre 16 sh. pour Texercioe prdoddent.
L'assemblde a ratifid la nomination faite par le eonseil de M. Fdlix Vernes comme adminis-
trateur et rddlu les administrateurs dont le mandat prenait fin, MM. le baron de Neoflize et le comte Pillet-Will.
Carnet de Tactionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Socidtd Egyptienne d'irrigationsont informds que le coupon No.ll, montant du dividende de l'exercice 1906-1907, sera mis en paiement, au sidge social au Caire, k partirdu 31 Juillet courant. Les actions No. Ik 3,250recevront9 shellings et les actions 3,251 k 4,250, 26 shellings.
L'intdrdt de 8 shellings, en dchange du coupon No. lOdechacune des 1,715 obligations, sera mis en paiement k partir du ler Aoflt prochain.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: VOYAGES D'ETE A PRIX REDUITS.

La Khedivial Mail Line mettra en vente k ses Agences d'Alexandrie, du Cairo et de Port Said des billets spdciaux d'aller et retour qui permettront aux personnes ddsireuses de se rafraicbir par un petit voyage en Grece, a
^.Smyrne, Metelin, Constantinople ou en Syrie, de le faire a un taux rdduit pendant les mois de Juillet et Aout.
Les prix seront les suivants :
Ire Clas.se 2me Classe
L.E. L.E.
Constantinople aller et retour 10— 6.500
Smyrne et M^tdlin „ „ 7 — .5 —
La nourriture pendant deux jours de qua rantaine est comprise dans ces prix.

Des prix rdduits seront accordds aux passages par plusienrs hotels k Constantinople, comme aussi au Phaldre, Athdnes, etc., et si les passagers en premidre classe ddsirent rester a lord a Constantinople et retourner par le mdme vapeur, ils anront la facultd de le faire en payant Fes. 10 par jour pour leur nourriture.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION
